Executive Summary

Belle Chemical Company Plant's Risk Management Plan

(40 CFR 68, EPA Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions)

EPA Facility ID: 1000 0024 3373



Belle Chemical Company's Executive Summary:



Belle Chemical Company acquired the Methylamines Plant from Chemours on or about January 1, 2020. The Methylamines Plant was an existing plant located within the Chemours - Belle, West Virginia manufacturing complex, previously owned and operated by Chemours, formerly DuPont.



68.155 (a) ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Belle Chemical Company (BCC) is committed to protect our employees and the communities that are home to our operations, which are an integral part of BCC's way of doing business.  The Belle Chemical Company - Methylamines Plant is committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner, as our top priority every day is the health and safety of our employees, near neighbors, the community and the environment.  



The BCC Plant adheres to company policies embodied in numerous environmental, health and safety standards, as well as engineering standards. The policies are implemented through the Chemours Belle Plant Environmental, Health and Safety manuals. These manuals are available to all BCC employees via services agreement between Chemours and BCC. Included in these standards are the requirements on Process Safety Management (PSM), under OSHA. 



68.155 (b) THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Belle Chemical Company (BCC) Methylamines Plant is a continuous manufacturing operation producing amines and formamides. The manufacturing process includes the following regulated substances listed in the RMP regulations, used as raw materials, made as intermediates, or produced as products.



Toxics:

Anhydrous Ammonia



Flammables:

Monomethylamine

Dimethylamine

Trimethylamine



Plant property, where regulated substances are handled and processed, is se

cured by fence and manned by security personnel at all times.



68.155 (c) THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

 

Belle Chemical Company's general accidental release prevention program incorporates the following requirements and best practices:



?    EPA 40 CFR 68 - Risk Management Plans

?    OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals 

?    OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 - Hazardous Waste Operations & Emergency Response

?    Other EPA, OSHA, DOT, and State regulations

?    Generally recognized & accepted engineering codes and standards

?    Internal Safety, Health, Environmental, and Engineering standards



The Belle Chemical Company Plant's safety programs include:



Designing for Safety:



* A documented process technology system covering hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

* Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.

* Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

* Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.

* Quality Assurance ensures fabrication and installation in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.



Maintaining our Plant:



* Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.

* Contractors are trained and qualified.

* A work permit system controls hazards.



Operating Safely:



* Operators are trained and job qualified.

* Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

* Operators follow approved procedures.



Auditing our Operations:



* Routine safety inspections are conducted.

* Company, independent, and governmental audits and reviews are conducted.

* Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

* Critical safety equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.

* Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to staring up any new or modified equipment.

* Quality assurance of critical

equipment ensures fabrication and installation in accordance with design specifications.

* All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.



68.155 (d) THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There are no incidents to include during the previous five year operational period of either the previous owner or Belle Chemical Company.



68.155 (e) THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Belle Chemical Company (BCC) operates the Methylamines Plant located at the Chemours Belle Plant site. Through site services agreement, emergency response activities and efforts are provided by Chemours. Chemours Belle site personnel are trained and equipped to respond to releases of regulated substances. The program is summarized as follows:

* Plant personnel receive emergency response training.

* Plant emergency responders are trained.

* Emergency response plans are in place.

* Plant participates in emergency drills.

* Critiques are held on drills and actual events.

* The Chemours Belle Plant site is a member of the local emergency planning committee.

* The sites Emergency Response Team trains local fire departments and agencies in response techniques and methodologies.



If a Major Release Occurs:

* Emergency alarm is sounded.

* Plant Emergency Operating Center is activated.

* Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.

* Community emergency responders are notified and respond as appropriate.



68.155 (f) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Belle Chemical Company - Methylamines Plant strives to upgrade its processes, control technology, employee training, and inspection, repair and maintenance of process equipment in order to improve safety.



As part of the Belle Chemical Company Methylamines Plant process hazards review program, all processes are thoroughly reviewed on a specific periodic basis to identify risk reduction opportunities to improve safety. As a result of these reviews, several items have been implemented or are in the process o

f being implemented to enhance our process safety management.



* Revision of operating control procedures.

* Piping changes to aid in emergency venting of certain equipment.

* Construction of diversion / containment to aid in preventing certain process chemicals from entering the waterway.
